title: Parents can now buy 'anti-nightmare mist' to help kids sleep better at night
text:

As an adult, tucking yourself up in bed and settling down for sleep can be one of the best parts of the day.

But as a child, hunkering down for the night can be pretty scary - especially if they've been having nightmares.

It might prove difficult as a parent to convince your little one that all will be fine and that they should shut their eyes.

Though those days may now be a thing of the past, as Cuckooland have created a 'magic potion' that will encourage your child to sleep soundly this Halloween .

(Image: Cuckooland)

(Image: Cuckooland)

Called an anti-nightmare mist, the item is simply a sweet-smelling spray which parents can use around the bedroom to get rid of any monsters that might be lurking.

The formula contains lavender which is intended to help soothe and relax kids before bed.

Explaining the inspiration behind the product, Nathalie Davis, director at Cuckooland, said: "We often get a lot of parents asking us how to deal with nightmares and encourage a night time free of bad dreams.

"So we did some research and asked parents what their children woke up scared of in the middle of the night, and amongst others, goblins, shadow monsters and a green man called Dan were listed.

"We have racked our brains trying to think of a solution and now we think we have it, so we have developed an anti-nightmare mist, infused with lavender that can be sprayed around the room at bedtime."

Handling children's nightmares is a common discussion point among parents, with more than 100,000 posts being shared about 'nightmares' on Mumsnet and Netmums.

Child clinical psychologist Lucy Russell has shared some advice for parents on what nightmares mean to children and how to help them.

She said: "Nightmares are a normal part of child development. As children start to learn about the dangers in the world, as well as what death means, when they are about eight-years-old, nightmares can be the brain's way of processing this new information.

"Lavender is really relaxing for the senses, so this may help. I would advise to start using this mist an hour before bed, to help stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system and also to initiate the release of melatonin, the hormone that induces sleep."

Cuckooland's Anti-nightmare mist is sold for £4.95 and has proved so popular with parents that it's currently out of stock, but will be back on sale soon.

Check cuckooland.com for more information on availability.
description: If your little one is plagued by nightmares, one company might have come up with a clever way to get them to sleep
